content.caption: More than 160 high school students and chaperones from across Maine gathered for the event One Life Project - Youth Voice on Sept. 20 in Bangor to share their ideas for how adults can better help young people avoid substance use and addiction.

While the drug crisis has stirred widespread conversation about the availability of treatment and the role of law enforcement, we turned our focus to the long term: how Maine can prevent such devastation in the first place. The cheapest, least heartbreaking way to stop addiction is to support youth.

“Teen substance use or addiction is the origin of the largest preventable and most costly public health problem in America today,” states a report by the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse.

That’s because about nine in 10 Americans with substance use disorders started smoking, drinking or using other drugs before age 18. One in four people who started using any addictive substance before age 18 are addicted, as opposed to one in 25 who started using at age 21 or older, according to the center.

Addiction is a complicated beast. There are genetic components. Children are at greater risk if they experience a lack of attachment and nurturing by caregivers early in life, or if they have a chaotic home environment.

Influences outside the home play a role as well. Children are more at risk of using drugs if they are aggressive and impulsive in the classroom, do poorly on schoolwork, or have friends who use drugs, according to the National Institute on Drug Abuse. The riskiest time for children is during major changes in their lives either developmentally, at home or in school.
In this way, schools have become key, though often unwitting, players in the battle against substance use and addiction.

Most young people don’t use drugs, and only a small percentage of young people who use drugs become addicted. And while those children and teenagers may be among the most difficult to reach, it is possible to prevent their use altogether or delay it to a time when their brains aren’t so vulnerable. Experts say it often comes down to them forming positive bonds — whether to school, extracurricular activities or people.
How are schools trying to keep young people from using illicit substances? What do they need to make a greater impact? To what extent is it their responsibility at all?

We teamed up with the Maine Principals’ Association to ask Maine public school principals these questions and others. We worked with the U.S. attorney for Maine to hold an event where we asked young people how adults could better support them, to prevent substance use. And we spoke to many others who work with young people — who know how hard they can fall and how brightly they can shine.
In this project, we share what we learned.

The BDN would like to thank Lindsey Smith of the University of Southern Maine’s Muskie School of Public Service, the Maine Principals’ Association, the U.S. attorney’s office, all Maine principals who filled out the substance use prevention survey, and the students from across the state who attended the One Life Project - Youth Voice event on Sept. 20 in Bangor. This project would not have been possible without them.
